title: Information Disclosure which violate program privacy

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
please refer to the following report:
https://hackerone.com/reports/311289

It was noticed that TTS changed the summary and set the domain to example.gov as not to reveal to the public. But at the bottom of the page, "britta changed the scope from https://ci.fr.cloud.gov to None."

Recommendation:
Should only provide general message for such situation: "britta changed the scope"

## Impact

not much of impact. but violate Confidentiality of the program.

activities.message: Do let me know if this report is valid, if not I will self close. Thank you.
activities.markdown_message: Do let me know if this report is valid, if not I will self close. Thank you.

activities.message:
Based on your initial description, there do not appear to be any security implications as a direct result of this behavior.

If you disagree, please reply with additional information describing your reasoning.

Including a working proof-of-concept that shows one of these implications can be incredibly helpful in our assessment of these claims.
activities.markdown_message:
Based on your initial description, there do not appear to be any security implications as a direct result of this behavior.

If you disagree, please reply with additional information describing your reasoning.

Including a working proof-of-concept that shows one of these implications can be incredibly helpful in our assessment of these claims.

activities.message:
Hi rubikcube,

As mentioned, the TTS team change the title and information to hide the URL/domain, but your platform reveal such important information (the scope of the url is reveal for this instant). The program is not fully disclosed for this situation, therefore I believe the company who do set up the program do not wish the scope to be reveal for this case. Why not we invite TTS team into this discussion, and see if they are fine with this behavoir. 

Thank you.

activities.message: I believed 3rd party view will be good for this discussion, as to improve hackerone platform. Lets make this a win-win situation. Thank
activities.markdown_message: I believed 3rd party view will be good for this discussion, as to improve hackerone platform. Lets make this a win-win situation. Thank

activities.message: hi @willw, may I have your feedback on this report, if this is a valid issue regarding this platform. I noticed you change the title and summary, to mask/remove the domain itself. but the changes made to the scope had revealed the initial domain via  "britta changed the scope from https://ci.fr.cloud.gov to None.". Is this behavior appropriate? Wish to hear your honest and kind opinion. Thank you.
activities.markdown_message: hi @willw, may I have your feedback on this report, if this is a valid issue regarding this platform. I noticed you change the title and summary, to mask/remove the domain itself. but the changes made to the scope had revealed the initial domain via "britta changed the scope from https://ci.fr.cloud.gov to None.". Is this behavior appropriate? Wish to hear your honest and kind opinion. Thank you.

activities.message: Hi @bangrorox, I don't think we care about the impact to this report (#311289) specifically, but it would be nice for the behavior for `Limited` disclosures to suppress the content of any additional comments/activity including scope changes after publication.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @bangrorox, I don't think we care about the impact to this report (#311289) specifically, but it would be nice for the behavior for Limited disclosures to suppress the content of any additional comments/activity including scope changes after publication.

activities.message:
Thanks @willw for the feedback. 

Hi @rubikcube, As mentioned from willw feedback, it would be good if changes could be make to the scope for limited disclosure. As you can see, the comments/title are all suppressed for Limited disclosure, why the scope is not. It would be good if you can speak to your team and discuss again on the validity of this report, if best it would be good to submit SR to your development team to patch this issue. Thank you.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks @willw for the feedback.

Hi @rubikcube, As mentioned from willw feedback, it would be good if changes could be make to the scope for limited disclosure. As you can see, the comments/title are all suppressed for Limited disclosure, why the scope is not. It would be good if you can speak to your team and discuss again on the validity of this report, if best it would be good to submit SR to your development team to patch this issue. Thank you.

activities.message: @rubikcube any update on this issue from your team? Hear from you soon. Hope you value my/client's suggestion. Thanks.
activities.markdown_message: @rubikcube any update on this issue from your team? Hear from you soon. Hope you value my/client's suggestion. Thanks.

activities.message: This is not a security issue and the product is working as designed. Due to the specifics of that report there was a question as to whether or not the asset should be included in the report, it was removed from scope as to not draw confusion - the fact that the asset name that was removed from the report is within the report details doesn't post a security risk. Thanks for report and we hope to receive more reports from you in the future.
activities.markdown_message: This is not a security issue and the product is working as designed. Due to the specifics of that report there was a question as to whether or not the asset should be included in the report, it was removed from scope as to not draw confusion - the fact that the asset name that was removed from the report is within the report details doesn't post a security risk. Thanks for report and we hope to receive more reports from you in the future.

activities.message:
hi @coffeecup, firstly I don't understand your explanation and you don't get our (myself/client) suggestion. I would think this is a design flaw, which violated program's privacy and secure principles by not suppressing the "scope". 

Looking at https://hackerone.com/reports/240083 , this report (Violation of Secure Design Principles) also is a design flaw. This report also no PoC, also is also a conceptual explanation. why is there a huge difference in judging? As you know your platform is for bug reporting, which my report already show that your design flaw does not suppress information for limited disclosure where client want to suppress the information. Whereas, #240083 only just for payment notification. This I would say is a need, and as for my finding is a must for confidentiality.

I believed you should take this into great consideration and value our suggestion for fixing this flaw which violate confidentiality. And of cause, if this is not a flaw, your team could change the limited disclosure feature for the title to the following: 

"britta changed the report title." 

to 
"britta changed the report title from CI for [ci.fr.cloud.gov] can be logged in and accessible to CI for [example.gov] can be logged in and accessible".

I don't see a need for suppression on the title.

As for this " the fact that the asset name that was removed from the report is within the report details doesn't post a security risk"?? You sure?

Because our suggestion (*included the client) is not valued , I would like to share this and discuss on my network. Therefore, I would like your permission to disclose this report. Thanks.
activities.markdown_message:
hi @coffeecup, firstly I don't understand your explanation and you don't get our (myself/client) suggestion. I would think this is a design flaw, which violated program's privacy and secure principles by not suppressing the "scope".

Looking at https://hackerone.com/reports/240083 , this report (Violation of Secure Design Principles) also is a design flaw. This report also no PoC, also is also a conceptual explanation. why is there a huge difference in judging? As you know your platform is for bug reporting, which my report already show that your design flaw does not suppress information for limited disclosure where client want to suppress the information. Whereas, #240083 only just for payment notification. This I would say is a need, and as for my finding is a must for confidentiality.

I believed you should take this into great consideration and value our suggestion for fixing this flaw which violate confidentiality. And of cause, if this is not a flaw, your team could change the limited disclosure feature for the title to the following:

"britta changed the report title."

to
"britta changed the report title from CI for [ci.fr.cloud.gov] can be logged in and accessible to CI for [example.gov] can be logged in and accessible".

I don't see a need for suppression on the title.

As for this " the fact that the asset name that was removed from the report is within the report details doesn't post a security risk"?? You sure?

Because our suggestion (*included the client) is not valued , I would like to share this and discuss on my network. Therefore, I would like your permission to disclose this report. Thanks.

activities.message:
Hi @bangrorox,

Just to clarify you why changing asset would not **violate confidentiality** of the program, asset/scope is something already listed in program policy and not something meant to keep private on public program, on another side **title and comment** may contain something which is not public already and meant to be keep private, that's why we decided to fix that and not this.

in this case, the asset change you noticed is done for keeping track of the report properly, anyway as I said if you or anyone can access the asset on policy page already, what makes you think this should be kept private on limited disclosures? 

Regards,
@chessmast3r
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bangrorox,

Just to clarify you why changing asset would not violate confidentiality of the program, asset/scope is something already listed in program policy and not something meant to keep private on public program, on another side title and comment may contain something which is not public already and meant to be keep private, that's why we decided to fix that and not this.

in this case, the asset change you noticed is done for keeping track of the report properly, anyway as I said if you or anyone can access the asset on policy page already, what makes you think this should be kept private on limited disclosures?

Regards,
@chessmast3r

activities.message:
hi @chessmast3r,

I understand your standing, and glad that there is someone who can talk sense and explain in a well manner. 

Yes, I partially agreed with you. But there might have clients who does not even want the affected domain/subdomain's scope to be reveal to the public. It may contains *.example.com, *.sample.com, or even specific domain/subdomains in the policies. Not all clients would want to disclose the "affected/exploited" scope to the public. I know these can be found in the policies, but why would they want to tell public which are the affected ones? for limited disclosure?

But as a client for myself if I were to put up a program in your platform, I do not wish to reveal my scope changes in limited disclosure. I will choose to change my title, summary and scope to mask or even remove the scopes for limited disclosure. Why would I want to reveal the scopes, to allow more people to further exploit/enumerate the resolved finding or even bypass the patches on the affected domain, I would rather kept it as a secret by suppressing all necessary information and let them do their own enumeration/exploitation. 

Nevertheless, it is up to hackerone team to consider this feature. I believes there are more clients who will feel the same as me, and @willx is also one of them who think this information should be suppress. I do not see any cons in this approach; this change will only bring benefit to your platform and increase more confidence in using it. 

Thank you.
activities.markdown_message:
hi @chessmast3r,

I understand your standing, and glad that there is someone who can talk sense and explain in a well manner.

Yes, I partially agreed with you. But there might have clients who does not even want the affected domain/subdomain's scope to be reveal to the public. It may contains *.example.com, *.sample.com, or even specific domain/subdomains in the policies. Not all clients would want to disclose the "affected/exploited" scope to the public. I know these can be found in the policies, but why would they want to tell public which are the affected ones? for limited disclosure?

But as a client for myself if I were to put up a program in your platform, I do not wish to reveal my scope changes in limited disclosure. I will choose to change my title, summary and scope to mask or even remove the scopes for limited disclosure. Why would I want to reveal the scopes, to allow more people to further exploit/enumerate the resolved finding or even bypass the patches on the affected domain, I would rather kept it as a secret by suppressing all necessary information and let them do their own enumeration/exploitation.

Nevertheless, it is up to hackerone team to consider this feature. I believes there are more clients who will feel the same as me, and @willx is also one of them who think this information should be suppress. I do not see any cons in this approach; this change will only bring benefit to your platform and increase more confidence in using it.

Thank you.

activities.message:
Hi @bangrorox, 

Thank you for the additional information! We always welcome suggestion from our hackers and teams as well, we noted the feature suggestion made by @willw and will be considered.  

On the point of this report, as I already said, it might be a good feature to have, but it's not a security vulnerability and does not violate the confidentiality of the program by keeping in mind asset already listed in the policy, hence will be closed as Informative.

Thank you for your efforts for participating in our bug bounty program.

Regards,
@chessmast3r
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @bangrorox,

Thank you for the additional information! We always welcome suggestion from our hackers and teams as well, we noted the feature suggestion made by @willw and will be considered.

On the point of this report, as I already said, it might be a good feature to have, but it's not a security vulnerability and does not violate the confidentiality of the program by keeping in mind asset already listed in the policy, hence will be closed as Informative.

Thank you for your efforts for participating in our bug bounty program.

Regards,
@chessmast3r

Thank you much.
